title: Adjusting for Chance in Clustering Performance Evaluation
description: This lab explores the impact of uniformly-distributed random labeling on the behavior of some clustering evaluation metrics. Clustering algorithms are fundamentally unsupervised learning methods and evaluation metrics that leverage "supervised" ground truth information to quantify the quality of the resulting clusters. However, non-adjusted clustering evaluation metrics can be misleading as they output large values for fine-grained labelings, which can be totally random. Therefore, only adjusted measures can be safely used as a consensus index to evaluate the average stability of clustering algorithms for a given value of k on various overlapping sub-samples of the dataset.
